answer: Unintentional natural gas releases, including those resulting from accidental releases, are indeed subject to reporting. question: How do we report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir?
answer: To report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir, several factors need to be considered. Firstly, the facility must report CO2 and methane emissions from equipment leaks and vented emissions. Secondly, appropriate default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for storage stations or storage wellheads in gas service must be used. Additionally, the facility must report the specified quantities for underground natural gas storage facilities and indicate whether any equipment components are subject to the well site or compressor station fugitive emissions standards. Furthermore, Equation W–30 and default methane leaker emission factors for transmission-distribution transfer station components should be used to calculate component emissions from annual equipment leak surveys. The emission factors for different components and services in both Eastern and Western U.S. are provided in the tables, including population emission factors, leaker emission factors, and methane emission factors. These factors are essential for accurately reporting emissions from separate facilities injecting or withdrawing gas from the same underground storage reservoir.
truth: Underground storage and compression and transmission compression are two separate industry segments.  A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions from all applicable industry segments against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  For a response to the question related to multipurpose facilities and dual purpose equipment, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (see pp. 1606-1608 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).  If multiple owners or operators use the same underground storage operation, one designated representative must be appointed for reporting purposes.

question: What is the definition of "facility" for underground storage?
answer: The definition of 'facility' for underground storage of natural gas includes subsurface storage in depleted gas or oil reservoirs, salt dome caverns, and all wellheads connected to the compression units located at the facility that inject and recover natural gas into and from the underground reservoirs. It also encompasses processes such as compression, dehydration, and flow measurement, excluding transmission pipelines. The provided tables contain emission factors and component counts for various equipment and locations related to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and transmission compression. question: Why do natural gas storage facilities not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment.
answer: The reason natural gas storage facilities do not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment is because the regulations specify the use of appropriate default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for storage stations or storage wellheads in gas service. question: Does Subpart W require reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility or does reporting start only when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage?
answer: Yes, Subpart W requires reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility. The reporting includes CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various sources such as degasification systems, natural gas processing, storage tanks vented emissions, and injection of carbon dioxide for enhanced oil and natural gas recovery. Therefore, reporting starts from the salt dome mining process and continues throughout the operations for load balancing or storage. However, they do not directly impact the requirement for reporting emissions during the salt dome mining process as mandated by Subpart W.

truth: What constitutes a facility, how to determine the reporting threshold, and reporting of emissions from collocated and dual purpose equipment is as follows: 1) As a first step the reporter must determine the emissions from all equipment listed in 98.232(c) for onshore petroleum and production.  Per section 98.231(a) only sources listed in 98.232(c) need to be considered for threshold determination for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. 98.238 defines “facility” for the purposes of onshore petroleum and natural gas systems.  Per the requirements of 98.3 each “facility” must submit a GHG report for all source categories at that “facility”.  2) Note that while identifying onshore production emissions sources reporters have to determine whether the source is “on the well pad or associated with a well pad”.  The location of production wells within other facilities is inconsequential to this determination.  Sources on a well pad or associated with a well pad across the entire reporting basin have to be taken into consideration.  If your emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production are equal to or greater than 25,000mtCO2e, then onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities report as a separate facility and include all emissions sources listed in 98.232(c).  3) Except for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution, which have unique facility definitions, all other segments subject to subpart W are considered in the threshold determination for a single facility.  You would also include emissions from other source categories at your facility (e.g., stationary combustion).  If there are emissions sources that are dual purpose then the rule requires this piece of equipment to be reported under the majority use industry segment based on guidance provided in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (pp. 1606-1608).  4) For collocated industry segments, which cannot occur in the case of onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution due to the requirements in 98.231(a), EPA has provided guidance on emissions reporting in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14.  Based on the information provided, the facility cannot be reported as onshore production and natural gas processing combined (see point 1 above).  For all the other segments, the report should use guidance in points 2-3 above to determine the segment under which the facility should be categorized.

question: For liquefied natural gas facility equipment that is in gas service, is only the equipment listed in Table W-5 (Vapor Recovery Compressor) required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule?
answer: Yes, only the equipment listed in Table W-5 (Vapor Recovery Compressor) is required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule. The emission factors and component counts provided in the tables are relevant for understanding the impact of leaks and emissions from various equipment in gas service, but the specific requirement for reporting leaks aligns with the information from Table W-5.
truth: LNG facilities will not be surveying the valves, connectors, and other components that are in Gas Service under 98.233(q).  At an LNG facility, a compressor that recovers vapor, but is designed so that it does not have reportable emissions of methane-containing gas, such as a flooded screw compressor, or one with seals purged with pressurized nitrogen, will not be reported, in accordance with the rule and the EPA’s response in Response to Public Comments, EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1026-7 (see pp. 45-46 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part1.pdf).  Vapor recovery compressors use a population emission factor, hence there is no leak detection required.  Reporters have to count the number of vapor recovery compressors and use the population emission factor.

question: Do I have to calculate emissions from operational LNG storage tank venting at LNG storage facilities or LNG import or export terminals?
answer: Yes, you must calculate emissions from operational LNG storage tank venting at LNG storage facilities or LNG import or export terminals. The regulations specify the need to report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various sources including LNG storage, LNG import and export equipment, and well venting for liquids unloading. These factors can be used to calculate and report emissions effectively.

A pressure relief valve is a special type of valve and falls in the category of "other," so this emission source is included in the leak detection survey and required to be reported.  Regarding your first question: sections 98.232(g) and 98.232(h) do no include venting from LNG storage tanks as an emission source; therefore venting emissions from LNG storage tank are not required for LNG storage or for LNG import and export equipment.  However, if the LNG storge tank is blown down to atmosphere, then section 98.232(h) does require reporting.

question: At LNG Storage sites, how should pumps that are internal and submerged be treated?
answer: At LNG storage sites, pumps that are internal and submerged should be treated by reporting CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from equipment leaks. It is important to use appropriate default methane leaker emission factors for LNG storage components to accurately assess the environmental impact. Additionally, compliance with the regulations specified in the applicable paragraphs of the environmental regulations must be ensured. The default methane leaker emission factors for LNG storage components are as follows: Valve (Survey Method 1-6): 14.84, Valve (Survey Method 21): 9.51; Connector (Survey Method 1-6): 5.59, Connector (Survey Method 21): 3.58; Open-Ended Line (Survey Method 1-6): 17.27, Open-Ended Line (Survey Method 21): 11.07; Pressure Relief Valve (Survey Method 1-6): 39.66, Pressure Relief Valve (Survey Method 21): 25.42; Meter and Instrument (Survey Method 1-6): 19.33, Meter and Instrument (Survey Method 21): 12.39. These factors should be utilized for accurate assessment and mitigation of emissions.

question: Are natural gas distribution facilities required to report emissions from residential and commercial customer meters and associated regulator(s) under §98.232(i )?
answer: Natural gas distribution facilities are not required to report emissions from residential and commercial customer meters and associated regulators under §98.232(i). Additionally, the calculation of CH4 and CO2 volumetric emissions from natural gas driven pneumatic pump venting involves using Equation W-2 of §98.233, where various factors such as total number of pumps, population emissions factors, and concentration of GHGi in produced natural gas are considered. question: Please explain how many leak detection surveys must be conducted a calendar year?  Must a facility indicate in advance how many surveys will be conducted in the year?
answer: At least one leak detection survey must be conducted in a calendar year. If a facility chooses to conduct multiple surveys, the results from each survey must be used when calculating emissions. Additionally, the facility must report the number of years in the leak survey cycle if conducting surveys across multiple years, not exceeding a five-year period. The provided tables contain emission factors and component counts for different equipment and services, which can be used to calculate emissions from the surveys. The specific emission factors and component counts can be utilized to determine the frequency and scope of leak detection surveys required for accurate emissions calculation.
truth: For natural gas distribution, a facility, which is the collection of all distribution pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by an LDC, is required to do at least one facility wide leak detection survey per calendar year and has the option to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys; if the facility selects this option, the additional facility-wide survey(s) must be completed during the same calendar year in order to account for fixing one or more leaks in the annual GHG report.  If the facility chooses to fix one or more leaks and conduct another survey to determine that the component is not leaking, it must conduct a facility wide leak detection survey in order to account for fixing the leak(s) in the annual GHG report.  As leaks are random in nature and while some leaks are fixed others are likely to occur.  Therefore, a comprehensive survey is the only statistically relevant manner by which to establish facility-wide leak emissions rates and account for leaks repaired.  Please see the response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1014-9 (Response to Comments, pp. 1281-1282, http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf) for further details.  It is very important to note that the requirement to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys should a company wish to account for fixing a leak does not preclude in any way a company from repairing a leak.  If a company chooses to conduct only one facility-wide leak detection survey in a calendar year but finds a leak during the survey, the company can and is encouraged to fix the leak.  The leak detected though, as noted above, must be reported as a leaker for the entire calendar year should the company choose not to conduct a second survey.

The answer also mentions the availability of emission factors and component counts in the provided tables, which can be used to calculate emissions from the surveys.

question: What happens if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components?  Could EPA provide a sunset provision so that annual leak surveys would no longer be required?
answer: Based on the provided information, the owner or operator of natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct equipment leak surveys at all above grade transmission-distribution transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period. If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, the number of transmission-distribution transfer stations that are monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle. Therefore, if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components, EPA may consider providing a sunset provision so that annual leak surveys would no longer be required, subject to the approval criteria and timing specified in the regulations. Additionally, the provided emission factors and population emission factors for various components and equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and processing can be used to assess and monitor the environmental impact of these operations. The equations provided offer conversion factors and calculations for emissions, providing a comprehensive understanding of the environmental impact of these activities.
context:
Based on the provided information, the owner or operator of natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct equipment leak surveys at all above grade transmission-distribution transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period. If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, the number of transmission-distribution transfer stations that are monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle. Therefore, if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components, EPA may consider providing a sunset provision so that annual leak surveys would no longer be required, subject to the approval criteria and timing specified in the regulations.{

truth: Equipment/component leaks are random in nature and minimal leaks in one year do not guarantee similar leak levels in the future.  There are no sunsetting provisions for individual emissions sources, only facilities.  EPA has provided provisions that allow facilities to stop reporting under certain conditions and with prior notification to EPA.  Please see 40 CFR 98.2(i) (1) – (i) (3).  EPA addressed sunset provisions in general in the proposal to the 2009 Mandatory Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Rule (74 FR 16478).

EPA’s objection to the comment to monitor 10% of stations per year would have been inconsistent with a five-year cycle.  Yes.   According to 98.233(q)(8)(i), “Natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct leak detection at T-D transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period to cover all T-D transfer stations.  If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, then the number of T-D transfer stations monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle without monitoring the same station twice during the multiple year survey.”  EPA confirms that an approach of conducting monitoring at 10% of the facilities in each of the first two years, followed by 40%, 20% and 20% in years three, four and five would be consistent with the rule language that the number of stations monitored be “approximately equal” over the number of years surveyed.

question: Do acid gas removal units which are used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units?
answer: Yes, acid gas removal units used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units as they are designed to separate hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators. The provided table data contains emission factors and component counts for various equipment and services related to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, and boosting facilities, as well as crude oil production equipment. However, the table data does not directly relate to the definition of acid gas removal units or their application in sweetening liquid streams.
truth: The definition of acid gas removal unit in §98.238 states, “process unit that separates hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators.”  Acid gas removal units processing a liquid stream do not meet this definition, and reporters do not need to report emissions from these units.

question: If all of the emissions from an AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside of the facility, does the facility still need to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then "reduce" the emission to zero?
answer: Yes, if all of the CO2 emissions from the AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside the facility, the facility still needs to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then 'reduce' the emission to zero. This calculation involves using Equation W-2 to determine CH4 and CO2 volumetric emissions from natural gas driven pneumatic pump venting. The assumptions for the calculation include a default value of 86 hours for T, a concentration of 95% for CH4, and 1% for CO2, and an emission factor of 37.3 scf/hour/component for High Continuous Bleed Pneumatic Device Vents. Additionally, the facility should consider the population emission factors and average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and crude oil production equipment as per the provided tables. These factors and counts will contribute to the overall emissions calculation and reduction efforts as required by the regulation.
truth: With regards to acid gas injection wells and subparts PP and UU, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response to Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.  EPA requires reporters to calculate emissions from AGR units and then adjust them downwards by the amount transferred outside of the facility.  Therefore, if 100% of the CO2 recovered from an AGR unit is transferred outside of the facility, then CO2 emissions from the AGR unit must be calculated prior to determining the amount being transferred outside the facility.  Note that §98.236(c)(3) requires separate reporting of both the AGR emissions and emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility, even if the values are the same.

question: Will EPA approve the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) relating to the measurement of individual compressor vents routed a common manifold?
answer: EPA approves the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) for the measurement of individual compressor vents routed to a common manifold. The regulations specify that for a compressor source that is part of a manifolded group of compressor sources, combined volumetric emissions from the manifolded group of compressor sources can be measured at the common vent stack. The measurements must be conducted at the specified frequency, and there are specific methods for performing as found measurements and continuous measurements for both centrifugal and reciprocating compressor sources. Additionally, the provided table data includes population emission factors for various components in the Eastern and Western U.S., average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, average component counts for major crude oil production equipment, and leaker emission factors for different equipment and services. This information can be used to further understand and implement the approved Subpart W BAMM for monitoring individual compressor vents routed to a common manifold.
truth: Facilities approved to use BAMM are still required to use the calculation methodologies and equations in § 98.233, and must comply with the reporting requirements in § 98.236.  The totality of the circumstances related to conducting measurement on compressors vents routed to a common manifold, if fully explained in a proper Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) request, may be considered by EPA to constitute unique or unusual circumstances justifying the use of BAMM. Pursuant to a May 2013 final rule, Subpart W BAMM requests are due by June 30 of the year prior to the year in which reports are due (the “reporting year”) and for which BAMM is sought. As June 30, 2013 falls on a weekend, BAMM requests for the 2014 reporting year are due by July 1, 2013.

question: The emission methods for dehydrator vents with daily throughputs less than 0.4 MMscfd in the preamble (use flow rate of wet NG and EF) contradict the requirements in the rule (use dehydrator count and EF).

truth: Under §98.232(e), emissions from flare stacks are not required to be reported as a separate emission source for onshore natural gas transmission compression facilities.  However, this does not exclude the reporting of flared emissions from the other emission sources listed in §98.232(e) if they are routed to a flare.  The flare source type in §98.233(n) covers only emissions that are not reported in association with any of the other source types in §98.233; see §98.233(n)(10).  For example, if transmission storage tank emissions are going to a flare, then the rule requires the adjustment of transmission storage tank emissions sent to flare per §98.233(k)(4).  The flared transmission storage tank emissions, however, have to be reported as transmission storage tank emissions under §98.236(c)(9).

truth: 40 CFR § 98.238 defines a flare as “…a combustion device, whether at ground level or elevated, that uses an open or closed flame to combust waste gases without energy recovery.”  An open pipe without combustion would not be considered a flare, but any hydrocarbon releases through it would be considered “vented emissions” under §98.238, which includes “process designed flow to the atmosphere through seals or vent pipes.”
